Front:
Your organization needs to grant temporary elevated access to Azure resources for administrators who require it only occasionally. The solution must enforce approval workflows and provide detailed audit logs. Which feature should you implement?

A) Assign permanent Azure RBAC roles to administrators
B) Implement Microsoft Entra Privileged Identity Management (PIM)
C) Create custom roles with limited permissions
Back:
B) Implement Microsoft Entra Privileged Identity Management (PIM). PIM provides just-in-time privileged access with approval workflows, time-bound assignments, access reviews, and comprehensive audit trails.

Reference: Configure PIM
Extra: PIM enables zero standing privileges through JIT access. Requires justification for activation, supports multi-stage approval, enforces MFA for elevation, time-limits assignments (hours), provides alerts on suspicious activations. Permanent roles (option A) violate least privilege. Custom roles (option C) don't provide time-limited access. PIM features: eligible vs active assignments, activation duration (1-24 hours), notification on activation, access reviews, activation history. Best practice: make all privileged roles eligible, require approval for critical roles.

Front:
A multi-tier web application requires different levels of access control: the web tier needs read access to the database, the API tier needs read/write access, and the admin portal needs full control. How should you implement least privilege access?

A) Use a single Azure RBAC role with full permissions for all tiers
B) Create custom Azure RBAC roles with specific permissions for each tier
C) Use shared access keys distributed to each tier
Back:
B) Create custom Azure RBAC roles with specific permissions for each tier. Custom roles enable granular permission assignments matching each tier's exact requirements, implementing principle of least privilege.

Reference: Custom Azure Roles
Extra: Custom roles use Actions (allowed operations) and NotActions (explicitly denied). Example: WebTierRole allows Microsoft.Sql/*/read, ApiTierRole adds */write, AdminRole includes */delete. Single role (option A) violates least privilege. Shared keys (option C) don't provide granular control and are harder to rotate. Custom role best practices: use built-in roles as templates, scope roles narrowly (resource group level), regularly review permissions. Combine with managed identities for passwordless auth. Use Azure Policy to enforce role assignments. Maximum 5000 custom roles per tenant.

Front:
An Azure application needs to authenticate to Azure Key Vault to retrieve secrets without storing credentials in code or configuration files. What authentication method should you implement?

A) Store connection strings in application settings
B) Use managed identity assigned to the application
C) Generate SAS tokens for Key Vault access
Back:
B) Use managed identity assigned to the application. Managed identity provides automatic credential management and Azure AD authentication without storing secrets, enabling secure, passwordless access to Key Vault.

Reference: Managed Identities Overview
Extra: Managed identities eliminate credential management: system-assigned (tied to resource lifecycle) or user-assigned (shared across resources). Assign "Key Vault Secrets User" role to the identity. Connection strings (option A) are credentials to protect, not solutions. SAS tokens (option C) need rotation. Managed identity benefits: automatic credential rotation, works with 100+ Azure services, no code changes for rotation, audit trail via Azure AD. Code uses DefaultAzureCredential to authenticate. Supported by: VMs, App Service, Functions, AKS, Container Apps, Logic Apps.

Front:
Your organization must enforce multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all users accessing Azure resources from untrusted locations but not from corporate networks. How should you configure this?

A) Enable MFA for all users globally in Azure AD settings
B) Create a Conditional Access policy based on location
C) Configure per-user MFA settings for each user
Back:
B) Create a Conditional Access policy based on location. Conditional Access evaluates signals (location, device, risk) and enforces MFA selectively based on conditions, enabling risk-based access control.

Reference: Conditional Access Overview
Extra: Conditional Access policy: If (Untrusted Location) Then (Require MFA). Named locations define trusted IPs/countries. Global MFA (option A) can't distinguish locations. Per-user MFA (option C) lacks location awareness. Conditional Access signals: user/group, cloud apps, device state, location (IP ranges), risk (identity protection), device platform. Grant controls: require MFA, compliant device, hybrid joined device, approved app. Session controls: limit session lifetime, app enforced restrictions. Requires Azure AD Premium P1. Use report-only mode to test policies before enforcement.

Front:
An enterprise application requires federated authentication with Azure AD and needs API permissions to read user profiles and send emails on behalf of users. How should you configure the application registration?

A) Request only application permissions without user consent
B) Configure delegated permissions with admin consent for organization
C) Use client credentials flow with application permissions
Back:
B) Configure delegated permissions with admin consent for organization. Delegated permissions run in user context ("on behalf of"), appropriate for user-interactive apps. Admin consent grants permissions organization-wide.

Reference: App Permissions and Consent
Extra: Permission types: Delegated (on behalf of signed-in user, requires user presence), Application (app identity, background services). Read profiles + send emails requires delegated (user context). Application permissions (option A, C) are for services/daemons without user interaction. Consent types: User consent (low-risk permissions), Admin consent (sensitive permissions, tenant-wide). Define scopes in API app registration. Requesting app references these scopes. Least privilege: request minimum necessary permissions. OAuth 2.0 permission scopes format: api://appid/scope. Microsoft Graph permissions: User.Read, Mail.Send.

Front:
A web application deployed in Azure App Service must access Azure SQL Database securely without connection strings exposed in configuration. What combination provides the most secure access?

A) Store connection string in App Service application settings
B) Use managed identity with Azure AD authentication to SQL
C) Store connection string in Azure Key Vault and reference from App Service
Back:
B) Use managed identity with Azure AD authentication to SQL. Enables passwordless authentication, eliminates connection string management, provides automatic credential rotation, and leverages Azure AD for access control.

Reference: Connect with Managed Identity
Extra: Configuration: 1) Enable system-assigned managed identity on App Service, 2) Enable Azure AD authentication on SQL Server, 3) Create contained database user for managed identity, 4) Grant SQL permissions, 5) Use Azure.Identity library in code. App settings (option A) still expose credentials. Key Vault (option C) is better but managed identity is simpler. ConnectionString with managed identity: "Server=server.database.windows.net;Authentication=Active Directory Managed Identity". Benefits: no secrets in code/config, automatic rotation, centralized access management. Works with SQL Database, SQL Managed Instance, Synapse Analytics.

Front:
Your company requires that all Network Security Group (NSG) rules are reviewed and approved before deployment. Which governance approach ensures compliance?

A) Use Azure Policy to audit and enforce NSG rule standards
B) Manually review NSG rules after deployment
C) Implement Azure Advisor recommendations
Back:
A) Use Azure Policy to audit and enforce NSG rule standards. Azure Policy evaluates resources against defined rules, can audit non-compliant configurations, and deny deployments that violate security policies.

Reference: Azure Policy Overview
Extra: Azure Policy for NSGs: audit rules allowing RDP/SSH from internet (0.0.0.0/0), deny creation of overly permissive rules, require specific tags. Manual review (option B) doesn't prevent deployment. Advisor (option C) provides recommendations, not enforcement. Policy effects: Audit (log non-compliance), Deny (prevent creation), Modify (auto-remediate), DeployIfNotExists (deploy remediation). Built-in policies: "Management ports should be closed on VMs", "Internet-facing VMs should be protected with NSGs". Use policy initiatives (groups of policies) for comprehensive security baselines. Compliance reports show violations across subscriptions.

Front:
A virtual network hosting production servers must allow HTTP/HTTPS traffic but deny all other inbound internet traffic. What is the most secure way to configure this?

A) Create NSG rules allowing HTTP/HTTPS and default deny rule
B) Use Azure Firewall with application rules for HTTP/HTTPS
C) Configure Application Security Groups for web servers
Back:
A) Create NSG rules allowing HTTP/HTTPS and default deny rule. NSGs provide stateful packet filtering at subnet/NIC level. Explicit allow rules for ports 80/443, implicit deny for all other traffic ensures least privilege.

Reference: Network Security Groups
Extra: NSG best practices: Default deny (NSGs have implicit deny all), Explicit allows only, Lowest priority number = highest priority (100 processes before 200). Rule: Priority 100, Allow, Inbound, TCP 80,443, Source: Internet, Dest: VirtualNetwork. Azure Firewall (option B) is overkill for basic filtering. ASGs (option C) group VMs but don't define rules alone. NSG evaluation: more specific rules first, stateful (return traffic automatically allowed). Place NSGs at subnet level (covers all resources) over NIC level. Use service tags (Internet, VirtualNetwork, AzureLoadBalancer) instead of IP ranges. Maximum 1000 rules per NSG.

Front:
A multi-tier application has web, app, and database tiers. You need to allow web tier to communicate with app tier, and app tier with database tier, but prevent web tier from directly accessing database tier. How should you configure Application Security Groups?

A) Create one ASG and assign all tiers to it
B) Create separate ASGs per tier and configure NSG rules between ASGs
C) Use network virtual appliances between tiers
Back:
B) Create separate ASGs per tier and configure NSG rules between ASGs. ASGs enable micro-segmentation by grouping VMs logically and creating NSG rules based on those groups, simplifying security management.

Reference: Application Security Groups
Extra: Configuration: Create WebASG, AppASG, DbASG. NSG rules: Allow WebASG→AppASG:443, Allow AppASG→DbASG:1433, Deny WebASG→DbASG. Single ASG (option A) doesn't provide isolation. NVAs (option C) add complexity. ASG benefits: reference ASGs in NSG rules instead of IPs, add/remove VMs without changing rules, logical grouping matches application architecture. Each NIC can belong to unlimited ASGs. ASGs must be in same region/VNet as NSG. Example rule: Source=WebASG, Destination=AppASG, Port=443, Action=Allow. Enables zero-trust segmentation within VNet.

Front:
An Azure virtual network needs private connectivity to Azure Storage without traffic traversing the internet. Which solution provides direct Azure backbone network access?

A) Use service endpoints to route traffic over Azure backbone
B) Configure Private Link with private endpoints
C) Enable VPN gateway for encrypted connectivity
Back:
B) Configure Private Link with private endpoints. Private endpoints inject Azure PaaS services into your VNet with private IPs, providing network isolation and eliminating public internet exposure.

Reference: Private Endpoints
Extra: Private endpoint creates private IP in your VNet for Storage account. Traffic flows entirely through Azure backbone. Service endpoints (option A) use public IPs with backbone routing. VPN gateway (option C) is for on-premises connectivity. Private endpoint benefits: network isolation (no public exposure), private DNS integration, works across VNets/peerings, no internet breakout. Supports: Storage, SQL, Cosmos DB, Key Vault, App Service, 50+ services. Requires: DNS configuration (private zones), NSG rules allow traffic to private IP. Can disable public access entirely on Storage account. Costs: per endpoint + data processing.

Front:
A company with multiple Azure VNets needs centralized network management, consistent security policies, and simplified connectivity across VNets. Which Azure service addresses these requirements?

A) Configure VNet peering between each VNet pair
B) Implement Azure Virtual Network Manager for centralized management
C) Use VPN Gateway in hub-and-spoke topology
Back:
B) Implement Azure Virtual Network Manager for centralized management. Virtual Network Manager provides centralized management of network topology and security across multiple VNets with consistent policy enforcement.

Reference: Azure Virtual Network Manager
Extra: Virtual Network Manager capabilities: Network groups (dynamic VNet membership via Azure Policy), Connectivity configurations (mesh/hub-spoke topologies), Security admin rules (high-priority NSG rules enforced across VNets), centralized deployment. VNet peering (option A) requires individual configurations. VPN Gateway (option C) doesn't provide policy management. Features: automatic inclusion of VNets matching criteria, global reach (across regions), override local NSG rules with security admin rules, deployment at scale. Use cases: enforce security baselines, create mesh connectivity for multi-region apps, manage multi-tenant networks. Requires Azure RBAC permissions.

Front:
Point-to-site VPN clients need to connect securely to Azure VNet. The solution must use certificate-based authentication without managing client certificates manually. How should you configure authentication?

A) Self-signed certificates on each client
B) Azure AD authentication with Conditional Access
C) Shared access keys distributed to clients
Back:
B) Azure AD authentication with Conditional Access. Azure AD authentication for P2S VPN eliminates certificate management, integrates with Conditional Access for MFA, and enables centralized user access control.

Reference: Azure AD Authentication for VPN
Extra: Azure AD auth for P2S VPN: users authenticate with Azure AD credentials, MFA enforced via Conditional Access, certificate management eliminated, supports OpenVPN protocol. Self-signed certs (option A) require management overhead. Shared keys (option C) lack individual user control. Configuration: Create VPN Gateway (VpnGw1+), configure P2S with Azure AD auth, whitelist Azure VPN app ID in tenant, users install Azure VPN client. Conditional Access policies apply: MFA, device compliance, location restrictions. Requires: Basic SKU or higher, Azure AD Premium for Conditional Access. User experience: single sign-on with Azure AD credentials.

Front:
ExpressRoute provides private connectivity to Azure, but you need to encrypt traffic over the ExpressRoute circuit. Which encryption method should you implement?

A) ExpressRoute traffic is automatically encrypted
B) Configure MACsec for Layer 2 encryption at ExpressRoute Direct
C) Use public internet with IPsec VPN instead
Back:
B) Configure MACsec for Layer 2 encryption at ExpressRoute Direct. MACsec provides Layer 2 encryption between your network devices and Microsoft edge routers for ExpressRoute Direct connections.

Reference: Configure MACsec for ExpressRoute
Extra: ExpressRoute is private but not encrypted by default (option A is incorrect). MACsec encrypts Layer 2 frames between customer edge and Microsoft edge. Available only for ExpressRoute Direct (100 Gbps). For ExpressRoute partner circuits, use IPsec VPN over ExpressRoute using VPN Gateway. Internet VPN (option C) loses ExpressRoute benefits. MACsec features: 128/256-bit AES encryption, configurable cipher suites, pre-shared key authentication. Alternative: IPsec VPN over private peering (application-level encryption), Azure VPN Gateway supports BGP over ExpressRoute. For data-in-transit compliance: combine ExpressRoute + VPN Gateway.

Front:
A web application requires protection against SQL injection, cross-site scripting, and other OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities. The application uses Azure App Service. What should you deploy?

A) Network Security Groups with strict rules
B) Web Application Firewall on Application Gateway or Front Door
C) Azure Firewall with network rules
Back:
B) Web Application Firewall on Application Gateway or Front Door. WAF provides Layer 7 protection against web vulnerabilities using OWASP Core Rule Set and custom rules.

Reference: Web Application Firewall
Extra: WAF protects against: SQL injection, XSS, command injection, HTTP protocol violations, bots. NSGs (option A) are Layer 3/4, don't inspect application payload. Azure Firewall (option C) is for network traffic, not web apps. WAF features: OWASP CRS 3.2/3.1/3.0, custom rules (IP/geo filtering, rate limiting, string matching), bot protection, exclusion lists. Deployment options: Application Gateway WAF (regional), Azure Front Door WAF (global with CDN). Modes: Detection (log only), Prevention (block attacks). Tune with exclusion lists to reduce false positives. Monitor via Azure Monitor and Sentinel.

Front:
Internet-facing applications experience frequent DDoS attacks. The solution needs automatic attack detection, mitigation, and always-on traffic monitoring. Which Azure service should you implement?

A) Basic DDoS protection included with VNet
B) Azure DDoS Protection Standard plan
C) Azure Firewall with threat intelligence
Back:
B) Azure DDoS Protection Standard plan. DDoS Protection Standard provides enhanced mitigation, adaptive tuning, attack analytics, and integration with Defender for Cloud for comprehensive DDoS protection.

Reference: Azure DDoS Protection
Extra: DDoS Protection Standard vs Basic: adaptive tuning per application, attack analytics and metrics, cost protection (scale-out costs during attacks), rapid response support, discounted WAF rates. Basic (option A) provides infrastructure protection only. Azure Firewall (option C) doesn't specialize in DDoS. Standard features: always-on traffic monitoring, automatic mitigation (no user intervention), 99.99% SLA, protects public IPs on: Application Gateway, Load Balancer, VMs, Bastio n, VPN Gateway, Firewall. Metrics: DDoS attack packets, dropped packets, attack duration. Cost: $2,944/month + data processed. Best for: public-facing apps requiring high availability.

Front:
Azure Firewall must inspect and filter traffic based on fully qualified domain names (FQDNs) rather than IP addresses. Which firewall rule type should you configure?

A) Network rules using IP addresses
B) Application rules using FQDNs
C) NAT rules for destination translation
Back:
B) Application rules using FQDNs. Application rules provide Layer 7 filtering based on HTTP/HTTPS/MSSQL FQDNs, enabling domain-based access control that adapts to changing IPs.

Reference: Azure Firewall Features
Extra: Application rules filter on: HTTP/HTTPS FQDNs (www.example.com), FQDN tags (WindowsUpdate, AzureBackup), target FQDNs with wildcards (*.microsoft.com), HTTP headers (for MSSQL). Network rules (option A) use IPs only. NAT rules (option C) translate addresses, don't filter. Application rule example: Allow *.microsoft.com, *.windows.net on HTTPS from VirtualNetwork. FQDN tags are Microsoft-managed FQDN groups that update automatically. Rule processing: NAT rules first, Network rules second, Application rules last, first match wins. Use application rules when: SaaS services with dynamic IPs, content filtering by domain, protocol-specific filtering.

Front:
A hub-and-spoke network topology needs centralized internet breakout, threat intelligence-based filtering, and consistent security policies. Which Azure service provides this at scale?

A) Azure Firewall in secured virtual hub (Virtual WAN)
B) Network Security Groups at each spoke
C) Network Virtual Appliances per spoke
Back:
A) Azure Firewall in secured virtual hub (Virtual WAN). Secured virtual hub integrates Azure Firewall into Virtual WAN hub, providing centralized security, automatic routing, and scalable hub-and-spoke architecture.

Reference: Secured Virtual Hub
Extra: Secured virtual hub = Virtual WAN Hub + Azure Firewall + routing policies. Firewall Manager provides centralized policy deployment across hubs. NSGs (option B) are per-VNet, not centralized. NVAs per spoke (option C) lack centralization. Architecture: spokes connect to hub, all traffic routes through Firewall, policies managed centrally. Features: automatic route injection, inter-hub connectivity, integrated with Microsoft threat intelligence. Use cases: global enterprises, multi-region deployments, zero-trust network architecture. Routing intent enables: internet traffic (0.0.0.0/0 → Firewall), private traffic (RFC1918 → Firewall). Firewall SKUs: Standard (IDS/IPS), Premium (TLS inspection).

Front:
Virtual machines in different VNets need to communicate securely. The solution must support transitive connectivity and allow centralized security policy enforcement. What topology should you implement?

A) Full mesh VNet peering between all VNets
B) Hub-and-spoke with Azure Firewall or NVA in hub
C) Site-to-site VPN between each VNet pair
Back:
B) Hub-and-spoke with Azure Firewall or NVA in hub. Hub-and-spoke provides transitive connectivity through hub, centralized security, simplified management, and works with User Defined Routes (UDRs) for traffic inspection.

Reference: Hub-Spoke Topology
Extra: Hub-spoke topology: Hub VNet contains Firewall/NVA, Spoke VNets peer to hub, UDRs force spoke-to-spoke traffic through hub. Full mesh (option A) scales poorly (N*(N-1)/2 peerings), lacks central inspection. S2S VPN (option C) adds latency. UDR configuration: 0.0.0.0/0 (internet) → Firewall, 10.0.0.0/8 (other spokes) → Firewall. Benefits: shared services in hub (Firewall, VPN Gateway, DNS), policy enforcement at hub, cost efficiency. Use Azure Route Server for dynamic routing with BGP. Maximum 500 VNet peerings per VNet. Gateway transit: enables spoke-to-on-premises via hub VPN Gateway.

Front:
Just-in-time (JIT) VM access needs to be enabled to reduce attack surface by blocking RDP/SSH ports except when specifically required. Where should you configure JIT access?

A) In Network Security Group rules manually
B) In Microsoft Defender for Cloud JIT VM access
C) In Azure Firewall DNAT rules
Back:
B) In Microsoft Defender for Cloud JIT VM access. Defender for Cloud JIT automatically modifies NSG rules to restrict management ports and creates temporary allow rules only when access is requested and approved.

Reference: JIT VM Access
Extra: JIT VM access: default deny on RDP(3389)/SSH(22)/PowerShell(5985,5986), users request access with justification, automatic NSG rule creation for source IP/time window, automatic rule removal after expiration. Manual NSG (option A) lacks automation. Firewall DNAT (option C) is for inbound NAT, not time-limited access. JIT workflow: configure allowed ports and max time (3 hours default), request access via portal/CLI/API, approval (optional), temporary NSG rule added, automatic cleanup. Requires: Defender for Servers Plan 2, Contributor or specific RBAC role. Best practices: require MFA for JIT requests, audit JIT access logs, limit max time window (1-24 hours).

Front:
Azure Bastion is required for secure RDP/SSH access to VMs without exposing public IPs. What are the networking requirements for Azure Bastion?

A) Deploy Bastion to any subnet with /24 or larger
B) Deploy Bastion to dedicated subnet named AzureBastionSubnet with /26 or larger
C) Deploy Bastion as standalone service without VNet Integration
Back:
B) Deploy Bastion to dedicated subnet named AzureBastionSubnet with /26 or larger. Azure Bastion requires a dedicated subnet with specific naming and size for PaaS infrastructure deployment.

Reference: Bastion Configuration
Extra: Azure Bastion requirements: subnet name must be "AzureBastionSubnet", minimum /26 (64 addresses), no NSG on Bastion subnet (service-managed), no UDRs. Any subnet (option A) won't work. Standalone (option C) requires VNet integration. Bastion benefits: no Public IPs on VMs, RDP/SSH over TLS (443), protection against port scanning, Azure AD authentication integration. SKUs: Basic (50 concurrent sessions), Standard (unlimited sessions, Kerberos, native client, IP-based connection). NSG requirements: Allow GatewayManager inbound on 443, Allow AzureCloud outbound. Cost: hourly + outbound data. Use Bastion for: secure admin access, compliant deployments (no public IPs).

Front:
An AKS cluster must be secured with network isolation, private API server access, and controlled egress traffic. What combination of features should you implement?

A) Public AKS cluster with NSGs
B) Private AKS cluster with Azure Firewall for egress control
C) AKS with default networking and application gateway
Back:
B) Private AKS cluster with Azure Firewall for egress control. Private AKS disables public API server endpoint, uses Private Link. Azure Firewall controls outbound traffic with application/network rules.

Reference: AKS Private Clusters
Extra: Private AKS configuration: API server gets private IP in VNet, worker nodes communicate over private network, Private DNS zone for API server FQDN resolution. Public cluster (option A) exposes API server. Default networking (option C) lacks egress control. Additional security: Azure CNI for advanced networking, Azure Network Policy or Calico for pod network policies, integrate with Azure Firewall (UDR routes 0.0.0.0/0 to Firewall), authorize d IP ranges for API server access. Required egress: *.hcp.<region>.azmk8s.io (API server), mcr.microsoft.com (container images), *.blob.core.windows.net (storage). Use AKS-managed identity with RBAC.

Front:
AKS workloads need to authenticate to Azure resources (Key Vault, Storage, SQL) without managing secrets in pods. What authentication method should you implement?

A) Store credentials as Kubernetes secrets
B) Use Azure AD Workload Identity with OIDC
C) Use shared access keys in ConfigMaps
Back:
B) Use Azure AD Workload Identity with OIDC. Workload Identity enables Kubernetes pods to authenticate to Azure services using Kubernetes service accounts federated to Azure AD applications, eliminating secret management.

Reference: AKS Workload Identity
Extra: AAD Workload Identity: Kubernetes ServiceAccount mapped to Azure AD App Registration, pods use service account token, Azure AD validates token via OIDC, grants access based on managed identity RBAC. K8s secrets (option A) require rotation and protection. Access keys (option C) are static credentials. Configuration: enable OIDC on AKS, create managed identity, create K8s ServiceAccount with azure.workload.identity/client-id annotation, federate identity, assign RBAC roles. Replaces AAD Pod Identity (deprecated). Benefits: no node-level permissions, follows K8s native patterns, works with Azure SDK DefaultAzureCredential. Use for: multi-tenant apps, microservices, GitOps deployments.

Front:
Container images stored in Azure Container Registry (ACR) must be scanned for vulnerabilities before deployment to AKS. Which Defender for Cloud feature provides this capability?

A) Defender for Servers with vulnerability scanning
B) Defender for Containers with image scanning
C) Defender for App Service with code scanning
Back:
B) Defender for Containers with image scanning. Defender for Containers scans container images for vulnerabilities, provides recommendations, and integrates with ACR and AKS for comprehensive container security.

Reference: Defender for Containers
Extra: Defender for Containers includes: image vulnerability scanning (on push to ACR, on pull to AKS), runtime threat protection (suspicious activities), Kubernetes security posture (CIS benchmarks), admission control (block vulnerable images). Servers (option A) is for VMs. App Service (option C) for web apps. Features: integration with Qualys scanner, CVE identification with severity, remediation recommendations, compliance scanning. Policies: block images with high/critical CVEs via Azure Policy, enforce image signing/notary. Scanning: continuous (on push), on-demand, pre-deployment gates. Supported registries: ACR, Docker Hub, public registries. Cost: per-image scan + runtime protection.

Front:
Azure Disk Encryption (ADE) needs to be enabled on existing VMs. The encryption keys must be managed by the customer in Azure Key Vault. What are the prerequisites?

A) VMs must be stopped and disks detached
B) Key Vault configured with enabledForDiskEncryption and encryption keys created
C) VMs must be redeployed with new disks
Back:
B) Key Vault configured with enabledForDiskEncryption and encryption keys created. ADE requires Key Vault access policy enabled and keys/secrets stored in vault for BitLocker (Windows) or DM-Crypt (Linux) encryption.

Reference: Azure Disk Encryption
Extra: ADE prerequisites: Key Vault in same region/subscription as VM, enabledForDiskEncryption=true, KEK (Key Encryption Key) created, VM must meet size/OS requirements. VMs need not stop (option A) - encryption happens online. No redeployment (option C) needed. ADE vs Encryption at Host vs SSE: ADE encrypts inside VM (guest OS), Encryption at Host encrypts on physical host, SSE (Server-Side Encryption) encrypts at rest (default). Use ADE for: compliance requirements, FIPS 140-2 validation. Limitations: not supported on Basic/A-series VMs, requires 2GB+ RAM. PowerShell: Set-AzVMDiskEncryptionExtension. Monitor encryption status: Get-AzVmDiskEncryptionStatus.

Front:
Storage account data must be encrypted with customer-managed keys (CMK) stored in Azure Key Vault. The solution must support automatic key rotation. How should you configure it?

A) Use Microsoft-managed keys (default encryption)
B) Configure CMK with Key Vault URI and enable automatic key rotation
C) Store keys in Storage account configuration
Back:
B) Configure CMK with Key Vault URI and enable automatic key rotation. CMK encryption uses customer keys from Key Vault, supports key rotation policies, and provides customer control over encryption keys.

Reference: Customer-Managed Keys for Storage
Extra: CMK configuration: Key Vault in same region, managed identity for Storage account, Key Vault access policy or RBAC for identity, encryption key in vault. Microsoft-managed keys (option A) lack customer control. Keys not stored in Storage config (option C). CMK benefits: control key lifecycle, audit key usage, compliance with regulations (BYOK). Key rotation: manual (create new key version) or automatic (Key Vault rotation policy). Storage re-encrypts data with new key version automatically within 24 hours. Key hierarchy: KEK (Key Encryption Key) in vault → AEK (Account Encryption Key) → DEK (Data Encryption Key). Double encryption: infrastructure encryption + CMK.

Front:
Azure Files share needs to support identity-based authentication for on-premises Active Directory users and Azure AD users. Which authentication method should you enable?

A) Storage account key authentication only
B) Azure AD Kerberos for hybrid identities with AD DS sync
C) SAS token authentication
Back:
B) Azure AD Kerberos for hybrid identities with AD DS sync. Azure Files supports identity-based authentication via Azure AD, enabling Kerberos authentication for domain-joined VMs and NTFS permissions.

Reference: Azure Files AD Authentication
Extra: Azure Files AD auth options: Azure AD DS (fully managed), On-premises AD DS (hybrid sync with AAD Connect), Azure AD Kerberos (cloud-only). Storage keys (option A) are shared secrets, not identity-based. SAS (option C) lacks granular NTFS ACLs. Configuration: domain join Storage account to AD, enable Azure AD authentication, sync users to Azure AD, assign share-level permissions (RBAC: Reader, Contributor, Elevated Contributor), configure NTFS ACLs in files. Supported protocols: SMB 3.0+. Benefits: Windows ACLs, user-based permissions, seamless access from domain-joined VMs. Requires: Premium or Standard storage account, file share.

Front:
Blob storage contains sensitive data that must be protected from accidental deletion and ransomware. The solution must ensure immutable retention. What features should you enable?

A) Soft delete only for blob restoration
B) Immutable blob storage with time-based or legal hold policies
C) Blob versioning with lifecycle management
Back:
B) Immutable blob storage with time-based or legal hold policies. Immutable storage provides WORM (Write Once Read Many) compliance, preventing modification or deletion of data even by administrators.

Reference: Immutable Blob Storage
Extra: Immutability policies: Time-based retention (data immutable for specified period, e.g., 7 years), Legal hold (immutable until hold removed). Soft delete (option A) allows restoration but not immutability. Versioning (option C) maintains versions but allows deletion. Use cases: SEC 17a-4 compliance, HIPAA, FINRA, ransomware protection. Policy levels: container-level (all blobs), version-level. Policy states: unlocked (can modify policy), locked (cannot modify/delete). Combine with: soft delete (additional protection), versioning (maintain all versions immutably), lifecycle management (move to cold/archive). Cost: standard storage + policy enforcement.

Front:
Azure SQL Database needs Row-Level Security to ensure users can only access rows they own based on their identity. How should you implement application-level data filtering?

A) Implement filtering in application code
B) Create security predicate functions with Row-Level Security
C) Use separate databases per user
Back:
B) Create security predicate functions with Row-Level Security. RLS uses inline table-valued functions as security predicates to transparently filter rows based on execution context (user identity).

Reference: Row-Level Security
Extra: RLS implementation: 1) Create predicate function checking ExecutingUser against UserColumn, 2) Create security policy binding predicate to table, 3) Grant read permissions. Application code (option A) prone to errors/bypasses. Separate databases (option C) doesn't scale. RLS example: CREATE FUNCTION dbo.securitypredicate(@user AS sysname) RETURNS TABLE AS RETURN SELECT 1 AS result WHERE USER_NAME() = @user. Benefits: transparent to application (no code changes), centralized security logic, works with Azure AD authentication. Use with: managed identities, Azure AD users, contained database users. Predicates: FILTER predicate (SELECT, UPDATE, DELETE), BLOCK predicate (INSERT, UPDATE). Performance: use indexed columns in predicates.

Front:
Azure SQL Database must prevent exposure of sensitive data (SSN, credit card) in query results to unauthorized users while maintaining data integrity. What feature should you implement?

A) Transparent Data Encryption for data at rest
B) Dynamic Data Masking to obfuscate sensitive columns
C) Always Encrypted for column-level encryption
Back:
B) Dynamic Data Masking to obfuscate sensitive columns. DDM masks sensitive data in query results based on user permissions without changing underlying data, providing application-layer privacy.

Reference: Dynamic Data Masking
Extra: DDM masking functions: Default (XXXX for strings, 0 for numbers), Email (aXXX@XXXX.com), Random number (range), Custom string (padding). TDE (option A) encrypts at rest, not query results. Always Encrypted (option C) requires client-side encryption logic. DDM configuration: Mark columns for masking, Define masking rule, Grant unmask permission to privileged users. Example: Email column shows "aXXX@XXXX.com" for standard users, full email for authorized users. Limitations: doesn't prevent logical inference, not a security boundary (use with RBAC/RLS), doesn't protect from memory dumps. Use cases: call center agents (show last 4 digits), compliance (GDPR, PCI DSS), production data in dev/test envs.

Front:
Azure SQL Database requires column-level encryption for highly sensitive data (salaries, health information) with encryption keys managed by the application. Which encryption method provides client-side encryption?

A) Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) for automatic encryption
B) Always Encrypted with client-side key management
C) Storage Service Encryption for backups
Back:
B) Always Encrypted with client-side key management. Always Encrypted performs encryption/decryption inside client applications or Always Encrypted-enabled drivers, ensuring encrypted data is never exposed in plaintext to database engine.

Reference: Always Encrypted
Extra: Always Encrypted: data encrypted in client app, encryption keys never exposed to SQL Database, queries on encrypted columns limited to equality comparisons. TDE (option A) is transparent, not client-side. SSE (option C) is for storage, not database columns. Key hierarchy: CMK (Column Master Key) in Key Vault/cert store, CEK (Column Encryption Key) encrypts data. Encryption types: Deterministic (same plaintext → same ciphertext, supports =), Randomized (different ciphertext each time, highest security). Drivers: .NET, JDBC, ODBC with Always Encrypted support. Limitations: no sorting, grouping, indexing on randomized columns. Use with secure enclaves for richer queries in SQL Server 2019+.

Front:
Auditing requirements mandate logging all database access and queries to Azure SQL Database with long-term retention. Where should audit logs be stored?

A) SQL Server audit logs stored locally
B) Azure SQL auditing to Storage account or Log Analytics
C) Application logging in text files
Back:
B) Azure SQL auditing to Storage account or Log Analytics. Azure SQL auditing tracks database events, writes audit logs to Storage/Log Analytics/Event Hubs, enabling compliance reporting and security analysis.

Reference: Azure SQL Database Auditing
Extra: Azure SQL auditing: tracks database events (authentication, schema changes, data access), writes to audit destinations, configurable at server or database level. Local logs (option A) not available. Application logs (option C) miss DB-level events. Audit destinations: Storage account (long-term, cost-effective, up to 5 years), Log Analytics (queries, alerts, Sentinel integration), Event Hubs (real-time streaming). Audit actions: BATCH_COMPLETED_GROUP (all queries), SUCCESSFUL/FAILED_LOGIN, SCHEMA_OBJECT_ACCESS. Storage format: XEL files in blob container. Use Azure Policy: "SQL databases should have auditing enabled". Cost: Storage costs + audit data volume. Combine with: Defender for SQL (threat detection), Advanced Threat Protection.

Front:
Microsoft Defender for Cloud Secure Score is currently 45%. What approach improves security posture most effectively?

A) Ignore recommendations and deploy more resources
B) Prioritize high-impact recommendations based on Secure Score impact and remediate
C) Disable security policies to increase score
Back:
B) Prioritize high-impact recommendations based on Secure Score impact and remediate. Secure Score provides weighted recommendations; remediating high-impact items (MFA, JIT access, NSG hardening) raises score significantly.

Reference: Secure Score
Extra: Secure Score: percentage (0-100%) representing security posture, recommendations grouped into security controls, each control contributes points. Ignoring (option A) maintains poor posture. Disabling policies (option C) reduces visibility, doesn't improve security. High-impact recommendations: Enable MFA (+4% typically), Restrict internet access (JIT, NSG rules) (+3%), Enable encryption (+2%), Update software/patches (+2%). Remediation workflow: review recommendations, understand security control, apply fix (auto-remediation or manual), track improvement. Use filters: by severity (High/Medium/Low), by resource type, by compliance standard (PCI-DSS, NIST, ISO). API available for programmatic tracking. Target: 80%+ for production environments.

Front:
Multi-cloud environment includes Azure, AWS, and GCP resources. Centralized security posture management is required across all clouds. How should you configure Defender for Cloud?

A) Use separate security tools per cloud provider
B) Connect AWS and GCP accounts to Defender for Cloud with cloud connectors
C) Manually export data from each cloud
Back:
B) Connect AWS and GCP accounts to Defender for Cloud with cloud connectors. Defender for Cloud supports multi-cloud via native connectors, providing unified security posture, recommendations, and compliance across clouds.

Reference: Connect AWS to Defender
Extra: Multi-cloud setup: AWS connector uses CloudFormation/Terraform template, creates IAM role for Defender, scans EC2/S3/RDS/Lambda. GCP connector uses service account with Reader permissions. Separate tools (option A) lack centralization. Manual export (option C) doesn't scale. Capabilities: Secure Score inc ludes AWS/GCP resources, CSPM recommendations (misconfigurations), CWP plans (Defender for Servers on AWS EC2), compliance dashboards. Prerequisites: Defender for Cloud subscription, permissions in AWS (CloudFormation)/GCP (Service Account). Benefits: single pane of glass, consistent policies (Azure Arc for AWS VMs), centralized alerts. Supported services: AWS EC2, EKS, RDS, S3, Lambda. GCP VM, GKE, storage.

Front:
Azure virtual machines require vulnerability scanning without deploying agents. Which Defender for Cloud capability provides agentless scanning?

A) Microsoft Defender for Endpoint agent-based scanning
B) Agentless scanning using snapshot analysis in Defender for Servers
C) Manual vulnerability assessments
Back:
B) Agentless scanning using snapshot analysis in Defender for Servers. Agentless scanning takes disk snapshots, analyzes offline, detects vulnerabilities without agent installation, minimal performance impact.

Reference: Agentless Scanning
Extra: Agentless scanning: creates disk snapshot, analyzes in isolated environment, deletes snapshot, reports vulnerabilities. Agent-based (option A) requires MDE installation. Manual (option C) doesn't scale. Capabilities: vulnerability assessment (powered by Qualys/Rapid7), software inventory, file integrity monitoring, secret scanning (API keys, certs). Advantages: no agent management, no performance impact, scans stopped VMs, works with custom VMs. Limitations: requires Defender for Servers Plan 2, point-in-time snapshot (not real-time), additional costs for snapshots. Enable: Defender for Servers Plan 2 → Enable agentless scanning. Scanning frequency: every 24 hours. Combine with agent-based for: real-time detection (MDE), endpoint protection.

Front:
Azure resources must comply with PCI-DSS standards. Which Defender for Cloud feature automatically assesses and reports compliance status?

A) Secure Score for general recommendations
B) Regulatory compliance dashboard with PCI-DSS standard
C) Azure Policy for custom compliance
Back:
B) Regulatory compliance dashboard with PCI-DSS standard. Defender for Cloud includes built-in compliance standards (PCI-DSS, ISO 27001, HIPAA, NIST) with automated assessments and reporting.

Reference: Regulatory Compliance Dashboard
Extra: Compliance dashboard: shows compliance score per standard, maps controls to recommendations, tracks progress over time. Secure Score (option A) is general security, not regulatory-specific. Azure Policy (option C) underpins compliance but dashboard provides reporting. Built-in standards: Azure Security Benchmark (default), PCI-DSS 3.2.1/4.0, ISO 27001, HIPAA, NIST 800-53, CIS, SOC 2. Custom standards: create custom regulatory standards with Azure Policy initiatives. Dashboard features: control pass/fail status, linked remediation steps, download compliance reports (PDF, CSV), API for automation. Compliance assessment: automatic (no configuration), continuous (near real-time), based on Azure Policy. Use for: audit preparation, continuous compliance, attestation reports.

Front:
Microsoft Defender External Attack Surface Management (EASM) is required to discover internet-facing assets and security risks. What types of assets does EASM discover?

A) Only assets in Azure subscriptions
B) Internet-facing assets including shadow IT and third-party services
C) Only on-premises resources
Back:
B) Internet-facing assets including shadow IT and third-party services. EASM discovers any internet-reachable asset associated with organization (domains, IPs, web apps, cloud services), including unknown shadow IT.

Reference: Defender EASM Overview
Extra: EASM capabilities: asset discovery (passive reconnaissance), inventory (domains, IPs, apps, certificates, contacts), attack surface insights (CVEs, exposures, config issues), dashboard with risk priorities. Azure-only (option A) misses shadow IT. On-premises (option C) requires internet exposure. Discovery methods: seed-based (start with known domains/IPs), recursive crawl (follows relationships), third-party data sources. Asset types: domains, IP addresses, web apps, SSL certificates, ASNs, contacts. Insights: CVE detections, expiring certificates, exposed services (RDP, SMB), deprecated software. Integration: findings flow to Defender for Cloud, Sentinel connectors. Use cases: M&A due diligence, shadow IT discovery,continuous attack surface monitoring.

Front:
Security alerts in Defender for Cloud need automated responses (e.g., isolate compromised VM, create incident ticket). How should you implement automated remediation?

A) Manually respond to each alert in portal
B) Create workflow automation with Logic Apps triggered by security alerts
C) Wait for security team notification
Back:
B) Create workflow automation with Logic Apps triggered by security alerts. Defender for Cloud integrates with Logic Apps to automate responses based on alert type, severity, or resource conditions.

Reference: Workflow Automation
Extra: Workflow automation triggers: security alerts (by severity, alert type), compliance state changes (non-compliant resources), Secure Score changes. Manual response (option A) doesn't scale. Waiting (option C) increases risk. Common automations: Send email/Teams notification, Create ServiceNow/Jira ticket, Run Azure Automation runbook (isolate VM, block IP), Update NSG rules, Trigger Azure Functions (custom logic). Configuration: select trigger (alert with High severity), filter (contains "malware"), action (run Logic App), scope (subscription/resource group). Logic App examples: isolate VM by adding NSG deny-all rule, disable user account, snapshot disk for forensics. Test alerts: use alert simulation to trigger workflows without actual threats.

Front:
Microsoft Sentinel needs to collect logs from Azure resources, on-premises systems, and third-party SIEMs. What components enable data ingestion?

A) Sentinel automatically collects all data without configuration
B) Configure data connectors for each log source
C) Forward all logs to Storage account first
Back:
B) Configure data connectors for each log source. Sentinel data connectors ingest logs from various sources, transform data to Common Event Format, and enable querying in Log Analytics workspace.

Reference: Sentinel Data Connectors
Extra: Data connectors: 100+ built-in connectors for Microsoft and third-party services. Automatic collection (option A) requires connector configuration. Storage account (option C) not direct ingestion method. Connector types: Service-to-service (Azure AD, O365, Defender, 1-click), Syslog/CEF (Linux, firewalls), REST API (custom apps), Agent-based (MMA/AMA for Windows/Linux). Common connectors: Azure Activity logs, Azure AD sign-ins, Defender for Cloud alerts, firewall logs (Palo Alto, Checkpoint), AWS CloudTrail. Configuration: enable connector, grant permissions, configure data flow. Data flows to Log Analytics workspace, stored in tables (SecurityEvent, Syslog, CommonSecurityLog). Costs: data ingestion + retention.

Front:
Microsoft Sentinel requires automatic creation of security incidents based on suspicious patterns like multiple failed logins followed by successful login. How should you configure threat detection?

A) Manually review logs in Log Analytics
B) Enable built-in or custom analytics rules in Sentinel
C) Use Azure Monitor alerts only
Back:
B) Enable built-in or custom analytics rules in Sentinel. Analytics rules query logs using KQL, detect threats based on patterns, and automatically create incidents with necessary context.

Reference: Sentinel Analytics Rules
Extra: Analytics rule types: Scheduled (KQL queries, run periodically), Microsoft Security (Defender for Cloud alerts → incidents), Fusion (ML-based multi-stage attack detection), Anomaly (baselining with ML). Manual review (option A) doesn't scale. Azure Monitor (option C) lacks SIEM features. Built-in rules: 250+ templates (brute force attacks, data exfiltration, privilege escalation), based on MITRE ATT&CK. Custom rules: write KQL query, define frequency (5 min - 14 days), set alert threshold, map MITRE tactics, configure incident grouping. Example rule: SigninLogs | where ResultType == 'Success' and PreviousFailures > 5. Tune: adjust thresholds, add exclusions, suppress false positives. Enable: select rules from templates, configure parameters.

Front:
Security incidents in Sentinel need automated triage, enrichment with threat intelligence, and response actions. What Sentinel capability provides security orchestration?

A) Manual investigation by analysts only
B) Playbooks powered by Logic Apps for SOAR capabilities
C) Export incidents to spreadsheets
Back:
B) Playbooks powered by Logic Apps for SOAR capabilities. Sentinel playbooks (Logic Apps) automate incident response, enrich with threat intelligence, coordinate actions, reducing mean time to respond (MTTR).

Reference: Sentinel Playbooks
Extra: Playbooks (SOAR): automated workflows triggered by incidents/alerts, Logic Apps with 400+ connectors. Manual investigation (option A) doesn't scale. Spreadsheets (option C) lack automation. Playbook triggers: When Sentinel incident is created/updated, When alert is created. Common actions: Enrich incident (IP reputation lookup via VirusTotal/ThreatConnect), Isolate VM (run Automation runbook), Block user (disable Azure AD account), Send notification (Teams/Slack/email), Escalate (create ServiceNow ticket), Collect forensics (snapshot disk). Example: alert → check IP against TI feed → if malicious → block in firewall → notify SOC → update incident status. Permissions: Sentinel Responder role to run playbooks. Gallery: 100+ pre-built playbooks for common scenarios.

Front:
Azure resources are deployed via IaC using ARM templates/Terraform. Security assurance requires scanning templates for misconfigurations before deployment. Which Defender for Cloud feature provides this?

A) Scan running resources only after deployment
B) Defender for DevOps with IaC scanning in CI/CD pipelines
C) Manual code review by security team
Back:
B) Defender for DevOps with IaC scanning in CI/CD pipelines. Defender for DevOps discovers IaC files in repos, scans for misconfigurations, provides recommendations before deployment (shift-left security).

Reference: Defender for DevOps
Extra: Defender for DevOps: integrates with GitHub, Azure DevOps, GitLab. Scans: ARM templates, Terraform, containers (Dockerfile), secrets, code vulnerabilities (SAST), dependencies (SCA). Post-deployment scanning (option A) misses prevention. Manual review (option C) doesn't scale. Capabilities: IaC misconfigurations (public storage, no encryption, over-permissive NSG), secret scanning (API keys, passwords, certs), infrastructure as Code (discover ARM/TF in repos), pull request annotations. Configuration: connect GitHub/ADO to Defender for Cloud, install MS Security DevOps extension in pipelines, scan runs on commit/PR. Results: vulnerabilities in Defender dashboard, fail PR if critical findings. Prevents: deploying vulnerable infra, secrets in repos, policy violations.

Front:
Azure Key Vault stores production secrets and certificates. Network access must be restricted to specific VNets and public access disabled. How should you configure Key Vault networking?

A) Keep default settings with public access from all networks
B) Configure Key Vault firewall allowing specific VNets and disable public access
C) Use Key Vault access policies only without network restrictions
Back:
B) Configure Key Vault firewall allowing specific VNets and disable public access. Key Vault firewall restricts access to specified VNets/IPs, private endpoints provide complete isolation.

Reference: Key Vault Network Security
Extra: Key Vault networking options: Public endpoint with firewall (allow specific VNets/IPs, block others), Private endpoint (private IP in VNet), Disable public access entirely. Default public access (option A) exposes vault. Access policies (option C) without network restrictions allow access from anywhere. Configuration: Networking blade → Firewall, select Allow access from: "Private endpoint and selected networks", add VNet subnets/IP ranges, configure service endpoints on subnets (Microsoft.KeyVault). Private endpoint: creates private IP, works across VNets, disables public endpoint. Exceptions: "Allow trusted Microsoft services" (Storage, SQL, Defender for Cloud). Test access: Key Vault from unauthorized network returns 403.

Front:
Encryption keys in Key Vault must be rotated regularly for compliance. The solution should automate rotation and update dependent resources. How should you implement key rotation?

A) Manually create new key versions periodically
B) Enable automatic key rotation policy in Key Vault
C) Delete and recreate keys manually
Back:
B) Enable automatic key rotation policy in Key Vault. Key Vault supports automatic rotation with configurable policies, creates new key versions, and maintains version history.

Reference: Key Rotation in Key Vault
Extra: Key rotation policy: defines rotation frequency (e.g., every 90 days), expiry time after rotation, Key Vault automatically creates new version. Manual rotation (option A) prone to human error. Deleting keys (option C) breaks dependencies. Policy configuration: rotation interval (days), expiry duration, notification before expiry (Event Grid). Automatic rotation triggers: Key Vault creates new key version, publishes event to Event Grid, applications should reference key by name (not version) to get latest automatically. Key versions: previous versions remain accessible, applications using version-specific URIs must be updated. Supports: RSA, EC keys. Certificate rotation: auto-renewal with CA (Let's Encrypt, DigiCert), Event Grid notifications on renewal. Best practice: combine with automated deployment pipeline to update dependent resources.

Front:
Key Vault secrets need to be backed up and recoverable in case of accidental deletion. The solution must protect against malicious deletion by insiders. What protection features should you enable?

A) Rely on Key Vault redundancy only
B) Enable soft delete and purge protection on Key Vault
C) Export secrets to files for manual backup
Back:
B) Enable soft delete and purge protection on Key Vault. Soft delete retains deleted items for recovery period (7-90 days). Purge protection prevents permanent deletion during retention, even by admins.

Reference: Key Vault Soft Delete
Extra: Soft delete: deleted items enter "deleted" state, recoverable during retention period (90 days default), protects secrets/keys/certs. Redundancy (option A) doesn't protect against deletion. Manual export (option C) exposes secrets. Purge protection: prevents permanent deletion (purge) even by privileged users, immutable (cannot disable once enabled), requires soft delete. Recovery: list deleted items (Get-AzKeyVaultSecret -InRemovedState), recover (Undo-AzKeyVaultSecretRemoval), permanent delete after retention (purge). Backup: Backup-AzKeyVaultSecret creates encrypted backup, Restore-AzKeyVaultSecret. Use cases: accidental deletion, insider threat, ransomware, compliance (data retention). New vaults: soft delete enabled by default. Purge protection recommended for production vaults storing critical secrets.

Front:
Azure Backup data must be protected from ransomware attacks that attempt to delete backup copies. Which Enhanced Security features should you enable?

A) Standard backup only without additional security
B) Enable Multi-user authorization and soft delete for backups
C) Store backups in same location as production data
Back:
B) Enable Multi-user authorization and soft delete for backups. Multi-user authorization (MUA) requires additional approver for critical operations. Soft delete retains deleted backups for recovery period.

Reference: Enhanced Backup Security
Extra: Enhanced security features: Soft delete for recovery services vault (14-day retention for deleted backups), Multi-user authorization (MUA requires Resource Guard approval for critical ops), Immutable vaults (prevent deletion/modification). Standard backup (option A) vulnerable to deletion. Same location (option C) risks simultaneous encryption. Soft delete: deleted backups in "soft deleted" state, recoverable within 14 days, even if vault deleted. MUA: critical operations (disable soft delete, stop backup with delete data) require approval from Resource Guard owner in different tenant/subscription. Immutable vaults: once enabled, irreversible, prevents disabling security features. Alert on suspicious activity: unauthorized access attempts, backup deletions. Use for: ransomware protection, insider threat mitigation, compliance requirements.

Front:
Agentless scanning detected critical vulnerabilities on Azure VMs. What are the remediation options based on Defender for Cloud recommendations?

A) Ignore vulnerabilities as false positives
B) Apply patches via Update Management or Azure Update Manager, review recommendations
C) Disable scanning to avoid alerts
Back:
B) Apply patches via Update Management or Azure Update Manager, review recommendations. Defender provides specific remediation guidance per vulnerability, often requiring patches or configuration changes.

Reference: Remediate VM Vulnerabilities
Extra: Vulnerability remediation workflow: Review findings in Defender (vulnerability name, CVE, severity, affected VMs), Prioritize by CVSS score/exploitability, Apply fixes: OS patches (Update Manager), App patches (vendor sources), Config changes (disable service, update settings), Verify with rescan. Ignoring (option A) leaves risk. Disabling (option C) reduces visibility. Update Manager: automatic patching schedules, maintenance windows, pre/post-scripts, compliance reporting. Integration: Defender findings → Log query → dynamic group → Update deployment. Qualys vs Rapid7: both scan for OS/app vulnerabilities, CVE mapping, remediation recommendations. Track: fixed vulnerabilities, exempt false positives, export reports. KPIs: mean time to remediate (MTTR), % critical vulnerabilities patched within 48 hours.
